narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to close read philosophical texts with the goal of integrating them into religious studies.

In this course, we explored theodicy, providence, free will, and many other philosophical comments through the lens of the Book of Job, Saadia Gaon, Maimonides, Aquinas, and Gersonides. We learned how to do close reads of the primary sources and analyze them meaningfully. We learned different philosophical schools of thought and similarities and differences between Jewish and Christian thinkers

The course was insightful and taught us how to read medieval philosophy with an eye for specificity and details hidden in the text. After an introduction the problem of evil itself, we began discussing the general trends in how scripture/revelation and philosophy/reason were related throughout the periods from which we would read. We read contemporary philosophical reviews alongside primary texts from Saadia Gaon, Maimonides, Thomas Aquinas, and Gersonides. The knowledge was presented in the form of these readings, papers written by students each week, student presentations, and mini-lectures from Prof. Shemesh. We learned how to compare literature and philosophical arguments while also finding new perspectives to aid in our approaches to new philosophers.
Definitely learned more about Judaic scholars and their opinions on the problem of evil and how it can be solved
This course teaches you how to approach certain philosophical questions from different perspectives. It also helps to develop writing skills, and public speaking skills.
I learned a lot about medieval theologians and philosophers and medieval philosophy as well as interpretation skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is a really great way to become acquainted with medieval philosophers. However, the title is somewhat misleading: the class discusses summaries of the problem of evil as philosophers conceive of it but do not engage much with the issue by their own formulations.

Strengths: Great discussions, readings, and prompts
Weaknesses: Reading can be kind of heavy, and discussions get a bit awkward when most people didn't do the readings

The strengths were in the student papers and insight from Prof. Shemesh. Requiring students to read primary readings, then secondary literature, then synthesizing ideas really helped us understand the philosophy and argumentation in a class that only meets once a week. We had lively discussion and were able to have clear pictures of what was being discussed and why because of the background given. There really weren't any weaknesses. If there was something that could have gone better, I would have recommended that Prof. Shemesh gave us a greater focus/key details to look out for in the readings so that we may be more prepared or looking more deeply into the text.
Not really any weaknesses in y opinion, but some people may find it a little less structured of a class. Doesn't mean its a good or bad thing but may not be the best for some individuals
Readings were a lot- weakness

The strength of this course come from who is in it. Almost everyone in the course had some religious background and a strong belief system going in. Therefore, as we discussed topics from different religious perspectives, different people would offer unique perspectives. In addition, the professor, despite having his own belief, was able to keep everyone at a similar playing field and it seemed that everyone felt comfortable to contribute from their personal perspective. The weakness came in time management. Presentations were placed at the end of the class, so they were always rushed.

I really enjoyed the course. I wish we spent less time discussing student papers in class because it took away from our overall discussion and oftentimes us individual students didnt have much to say about other students papers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in philosophy. Abstract thinking is difficult for me, and this class is full of abstract thinking.
Yes! Fascinating class. Really cool intersection between philosophy and religious studies. It attracts a cool mix of Jews, Christians, and Atheists who all have fascinatingly different view points

Absolutely! Medieval philosophy has so much content and argumentation that challenges our way of thinking now. Prof. Shemesh is extremely receptive to students and was engaged in our learning from the very beginning.
IF you are interested in the topics of this course, I would recommend taking it. While it is a lot of reading, if you are interested in the material, you will want to read it and learn more.
I have come to conclude that I dont really like philosophy, so I would probably say no
If you are interested in the problem of evil and the perspectives of different Jewish thinkers (and one Christian thinker) on it, then absolutely.

Yes. I learned a lot and really enjoyed all the reading. Professor Shemesh is really fun and helps you learn well. Also I enjoyed the assignment format this semester, where we wrote short essays and responded to other students essays, then wrote a mid-sized final paper. It kept me engaged but not overloaded.
